headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Visa Inc.'s Fiscal 2011 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With us today are Joe Saunders, Visa's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Byron Pollitt, Visa's Chief Financial Officer. This call is currently being we
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Visa Inc.'s Fiscal 2011 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With us today are Joe Saunders, Visa's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Byron Pollitt, Visa's Chief Financial Officer. This call is currently being webcast over the Internet and can be accessed on the Investor Relations section of our website at www.investor.visa.com. A replay of the webcast will also be archived on our site for 30 days. The PowerPoint deck containing highlights of today's commentary was posted to our website prior to this call. Let me also remind you that this presentation may include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. By their nature, forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance, and as a result from a variety of factors, actual results could differ materially from such statements. These include setbacks in the global economy and the impact of new financial reform regulations. Additional information concerning these factors is available on our last 10-K on file with the SEC. It can be accessed through the SEC website and the Investor Relations section of our website. For historical non-GAAP and pro forma related financial information disclosed on this call, related GAAP measures and other information required by Regulation G of SEC are available in the financial and statistical summary accompanying our fiscal second quarter earnings press release. This release can also be accessed through the Investor Relations section of our website. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. And as always, thanks to all of you for joining us today. Visa delivered another quarter of solid financial performance posting net operating revenue of over $2.2 billion, a 15% increase over the same period last year. As has been the case f
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. And as always, thanks to all of you for joining us today. Visa delivered another quarter of solid financial performance posting net operating revenue of over $2.2 billion, a 15% increase over the same period last year. As has been the case for over a year now, these revenue gains were driven by double-digit growth in payment volume, cross-border volume and Visa-processed transactions from across the globe. Notably, 62% of our total revenue growth came from outside the United States, getting us progressively closer to our stated objective of having our business outside the United States represent more than 1/2 of our revenue by fiscal 2015. 
Net income for the second quarter were $881 million, a 23% increase over the prior year. This equates to diluted earnings per share of $1.23, a 28% increase over the second quarter of 2010. In the second quarter, we effectively repurchased an additional $630 million worth of shares nearly exhausting our $1 billion authorization first announced at the beginning of this fiscal year. Given that, and recognizing our ongoing commitment to return excess cash to shareholders, today, we are pleased to announce that our Board recently authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase program. This brings our total amount of repurchases in fiscal 2011 to $2.8 billion. Byron will provide some additional detail on the specifics of the activity. 
Before I'll be covering some of the business highlights from the quarter, I'd like to first address the ongoing legislative dialogue in Washington in the industry's efforts to address the Durbin Bill. Reiterating what I said on last quarters call, since the introduction of the Durbin amendment, Visa has worked with the industry to help educate legislators on the unintended consequences of this piece of legislation. And our efforts are gaining increasing traction. 
As you know, Senators Costa and Carter have introduced legislation calling for a delay in the study of the Durbin Bill. The Senators' efforts have generated support from a large, growing and diverse group of individuals and organizations who are concerned about the unintended anticonsumer consequences of debit regulation. We believe strongly that Congress should examine what the real impact of this regulation will be on consumers, the financial institutions that serve them, the payment system and the economy as a whole. This would be the reasonable and rational course of action. To that end, we are hopeful that the Senate will consider Senators Tester and Corkers Bill in the very near future. 
That said, no matter what happens with the Durbin, we will continue to compete in and lead the U.S. electronics payment market and be a growth company for years to come. 
I'll now turn to Business Developments from the past quarter that underscore our focus on driving global revenue growth today, while also setting the stage for future growth through new and innovative ways to pay. As ever, our strong relationships with clients continue to help drive our success. In addition to delivering solid financial gains in the second fiscal quarter, we were successful in advancing our strategy of growing and protecting our core business through key wins and relationship renewals with financial institutions and merchants. 
First, we grew our core issuance business with several important new deals. For example, in India, we've made significant strides in expanding our business with the State Bank of India. We signed a multiyear deal to issue Visa debit products across the SBI franchise, whereas until now the bank's business was entirely with our competitor. Nearly 1/2 million Visa cards have been issued since March and we expect several million to be issued within the first year of the program with significant runway beyond that. 
This new win is in addition to the joint venture we already have in the works with SBI and Alamon to terminalize major metropolitan areas of the country. We also recently signed a multiyear credit and debit agreement with HSBC, covering most of our Latin America and Caribbean region that will considerably broaden our issuance with HSBC in this part of the world. 
This builds upon the long-term issuing relationship we have had with HSBC globally for many years. And in the U.S., we expanded our credit program portfolio with a new 7-year program with U.S. Bank and Kroger, one of the largest grocery retailers in the U.S., which will begin converting to Visa in September. 
We also strengthened several relationships with longtime key issuing clients in the U.S.. Most recently, we resigned Regions Bank to a multiyear credit debit agreement to include signature debit, interlink and some processing services. Regions is a top credit and debit issuer in the U.S. and a longtime client of Visa. 
We also continue to see good traction on the prepaid front in the U.S. with our state government programs. We recently initiated unemployment insurance programs in Connecticut with Chase, and in Florida, with Wells Fargo. On that subject, our unemployment programs with the Bank of America in New Jersey and California are ramping up at a very nice pace. Importantly though, we are seeing increasing use of these cards at the point of sale versus cash withdrawals, ATM as consumers get more comfortable with this form of prepaid product. 
Beyond working with our financial institution and merchant clients to expand issuance and acceptance of our core products, we also continue to look ahead and develop new channels and form factors to diversify the utility of these products. 
For instance in the mobile space, we just announced our realtime messaging service with our first client, the GAP. This service allows merchants to send realtime location-based discounts and promotions to consumers via text message. In this case, consumers can opt into the GAP Mobile for You program to receive GAP discounts that are triggered when they conduct a qualified Visa transaction, which they can choose to redeem at a GAP store while they are on traffic. GAP was the first national retailer to test and rollout realtime messaging and we have a strong pipeline of other retailers to follow. 
This is an excellent example of a value-added service that supports merchants' desires to personalize the consumer shopping experience made possible by the realtime processing capabilities and unparalleled data from our Visa Net processing infrastructure. 
Equally important is the legislation has not delayed, ITM along with other offerings such as CyberSource's enhanced with decision manager, which I'll talk about in a moment, are the types of Visa value-added services that would consent merchants to route transactions over Visa Net. 
In the area of person-to-person payments, we continue to make important strides in leveraging our network and significant card base to enable people to pay each other using Visa cards. Our recent announcement with Cash Edge and Price Serve in the U.S. underscores one of the important ways we are accelerating growth in this area. Increasingly by working with partners like these, we have existing distribution channels, we can broaden the reach and ease of use of the prepayment programs of Visa products. 
A recent example of one of these P2P programs overseas involves a service we recently launched in Russia and the Ukraine. We are working with Kiwi, Russia's largest payment kiosk operator, first processing bank in Russia and Pre Bank Ukraine's largest bank. Together, we are enabling domestic transfers within Russia and with the cross-border functionality between Visa account holders in the U.K. and Russia. Over time, we will partner with additional entities to expand these programs globally. 
On the eCommerce front, we closed PlaySpan the acquisition on March 1. In the meantime, we have seen CyberSource's business continue to grow rapidly and gain increasing traction in the marketplace. During the quarter, CyberSource delivered 38% global transaction growth and secured a number of new business wins with major merchants including IDS, America and Olympus America. I also want to point out one or more of the recent examples of the synergies we are finding with CyberSource that deliver tangible value to our global merchant base. 
This quarter, we combined the strength of Visa and CyberSource's individual fraud detection capabilities to launch our first iteration of enhanced decision manager, which I mentioned earlier. By combining the risk force that CyberSource has historically provided to its merchants clients with data from the Visa Inc. advanced authorization service, we are delivering a unique and unparalleled view of transaction data that merchant clients recognize will serve them as a powerful new fraud detection mechanism with their business. 
All of these advancements are important steps towards capturing the enormous we see ahead, with payments innovation fueling our business growth over the moderate to long term. All of us know the way people connect and transact across the globe is changing dramatically driven by 2 global forces. First, the continued secular shift from paper base to electronic payments that still largely occurs at the physical point of sale, and second, the widespread adoption of global and Internet technology. These forces our conversion, and consumers and merchants are looking for payment solutions that harness these technologies. To that end, we have been working hard to develop a Visa quality payment solution that brings reliability, security and convenience to mobile and eCommerce environments. 
In our view, a globally viable payment solution must have 5 fundamental characteristics: convenience and simplicity, standardization, interoperability, global accessibility and security. None of the solutions we have seen from competitors is comprehensive enough because they don't address all of these criteria at once. Visa has long delivered solutions at the physical point of sale that passed this test and we are applying the same standard in the online and mobile arena. 
Look for us to make an announcement of our global eCommerce and mobile strategy later this month. And now, I'll turn the call over to Byron

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. I'll begin with some overall observations. First, Visa's 15% net revenue growth was broad based with solid 10% growth in the U.S. and a very strong 21% growth rate in rest of world. As Joe mentioned earlier, over 60% of the quarter's reven
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. I'll begin with some overall observations. First, Visa's 15% net revenue growth was broad based with solid 10% growth in the U.S. and a very strong 21% growth rate in rest of world. As Joe mentioned earlier, over 60% of the quarter's revenue growth came from outside the United States. This means non-U.S. revenue is now 45% of Visa's total. Second, U.S. revenue growth has been supported by 5 consecutive quarters of year-over-year positive credit payment volume growth. Most recently, the months of February and March both comped at 11%, which is the first time we have seen double-digit growth since the recession. We are clearly encouraged by this strength. Third call out relates to client incentives. Incentives for the quarter as a percent of gross revenue was 16.7%, up from 15.3% in the first quarter. Taken together, incentives as a percent of gross revenue was 16% for the first half of the fiscal year, at the low end of our guidance. While we still expect client incentives to be in the range of 16% to 16.5% for fiscal 2011, if implementation of the Durbin amendment is not delayed beyond July, it is probable that we would see some upward pressure on this number as a result of potential actions we would take to mitigate volume loss with certain issuers and merchants. 
Fourth call out relates to Durbin. Whether the legislation gets delayed or not, we still expect to deliver revenue growth in the 11% to 15% range and earnings per share growth of greater than 20%. Finally, it's worth noting that beginning with the second fiscal quarter, our 3 key revenue drivers are now growing at double-digit rates, while comping double-digit growth in the same quarter of the prior year. This is true both globally and for the U.S., indicating that the strength of the recovery is now more broad based. 
Now let's turn to the numbers. First, I will cover our global payment volume and transaction trends for the December and March quarters, as well as more recent payment and transaction results for the entire month of April. I'll then cover the financial highlights of our fiscal second quarter, followed by our guidance outlook for fiscal year 2011. 
Global payment volume growth for the March quarter income in constant dollars was 13%, a modest decline from the 15% growth we saw in the December quarter. We saw the following breakdowns in the March quarter figures. In the U.S., payment volume growth was 12%, relatively flat from the December quarter. Rest of World payment volume on a constant dollar basis, grew at 15%, down 2 points from the 17% rate in the December quarter. Most recently, in the month of April, U.S. payment volume growth came in at 11%. Although not yet available, based on the trends we saw during the second quarter, we expect Rest of World payment volume growth to be higher than the U.S.'s 11%. Global cross-border volume delivered a solid 13% growth rate on a constant currency basis in the March quarter, down slightly from a 15% rate in the December quarter. There was notable drop off in inbound travel to Japan, Middle East and North Africa. In aggregate, these situations may have negatively impacted growth by about 50 basis points. 
In April, cross-border volumes on a constant dollar basis grew 13%. 
Transactions processed over Visa's network totaled $12 billion in the fiscal second quarter, a 13% increase over the year ago period and modestly behind the 15% growth rate we saw in the December quarter. In April, processed transactions posted growth of 12%. CyberSource billable transactions totaled just over $1 billion for the quarter, a very strong 38% growth rate over the same period a year ago. 
We continue to expect strong results in this part of our business as eCommerce growth remains strong in the U.S. and internationally. 
Now turning to the income statement. In our fiscal second quarter, gross revenue of $2.7 billion was up 16% from the similar period in 2010. Net operating revenue in the quarter was $2.2 billion, a 15% increase year-over-year, driven by a sustained economic recovery, previously enacted pricing changes and cross-border transaction growth. 
Moving to the individual revenue line items. Service revenue was $1.1 billion, up 24% over the prior year period. This is reflective of strong payment volume growth in the December quarter and the impact of pricing adjustments. 
Data processing revenue was $823 million, up 13% over the prior year's quarter based on strong transaction growth rates for both Visa process and CyberSource transaction. As expected and discussed previously, data processing revenue growth has moderated due to the impact of key contract renewals 2 quarters ago and by the prospective removal of certain offsetting Gateway pass through revenue and expense. 
International transaction revenue was up 14% to $624 million due to the sustained improvement in cross-border volumes during the period. As I mentioned, client incentive as a percent of gross revenue came in at 16.7% and are running at 16% fiscal year-to-date, on track with expectations. Approximately 65% of the year-over-year dollar increase in incentives is due to payment volume growth in client portfolio, about another 25% of the increase is due to non-U.S. client renewal. 
Total operating expenses for the quarter was $862 million, up 3% from the prior year. Increases in personnel, professional fees and general and administrative expense were offset by lower marketing in the period. Additionally, and I'll continue to remind you of this for the next 2 quarters, recall that we announced an earnings neutral change in income statement presentation related to revenue and operating expense associated with certain pass through activity. 
As a result, $55 million of revenue and expense, which was booked in Q2 fiscal year 2010 did not reoccur in Q2 fiscal year 2011. In Q2, this represented 3 percentage points of revenue growth. For the remainder of the year, these changes in presentation will continue to be earnings neutral and will affect revenue growth. 
The foreign exchange impact on net revenue in the second fiscal quarter was moderated by our hedging activity and contributed a positive 2% increase compared to the same prior year period. While our operating margin for the quarter was 62%, please note that we expect to aggressively fund important long-term investments across our entire business. 
Capital expenditures was $72 million in the quarter, representing ongoing investment in technology, infrastructure and growth initiatives. Lastly, the PlaySpan acquisition had a dilutive impact to earnings per share of $0.01 for the second quarter of fiscal 2011. And we anticipate a dilutive impact to earnings per share of $0.04 for the full 2011 fiscal year. 
Moving on to the balance sheet. We ended the second quarter in great shape with negligible debt and cash, cash equivalents, restricted cash and available-for-sale investments of $6.6 billion. Of this total, $3 billion is restricted cash, which represents amount sufficient to fully pay out the balance of the American Express settlement over the remaining 3 quarters with $2.7 billion uncommitted as of the end of the second quarter. 
In terms of our ongoing buyback, at the end of the quarter, we announced the prefunding of the litigation escrow by $400 million to be funded with cash previously designated for our $1 billion share repurchase. This was executed at an average price of $73.81 per share. Additionally, we repurchased $230 million of our shares in the open market during the quarter at an average price of $70.53 per share. Also we effectively repurchased 8.7 million shares at an average price of $72.58. This leaves us with $64 million of open to buy under the original program. 
At the end of the second quarter, we had 704 million shares outstanding on an as-converted basis. And importantly, the A class now accounts for almost 75% of our outstanding shares. Management remains committed to returning excess cash to shareholders. And for this end, as Joe mentioned at the outset, our Board of Directors authorized a new $1 billion repurchase plan, which we will execute at prices we feel are attractive relative to the long-term value of Visa. 
As to guidance, for the balance of 2011, given the results today, we are not making any adjustments at this time. With or without a Durbin delay, we expect to deliver revenue growth in the 11% to 15% range and EPS growth of better than 20%. Once the timing and content of the Reformed Act Regulations are clarified, we will determine whether any 2011 guidance requires adjustment, not just client incentives, and we will consider providing an early earnings outlook for fiscal 2012. 
In summary, we expect Visa to remain a solid growth company for years to come. Our core businesses continue to grow at healthy rates, while we are aggressively investing in technologies and platforms that will extend our core payment and processing capability, thereby creating new sources of growth. 
Finally, we expect to deliver this growth while driving significant free cash flow, which we will use to enhance shareholder returns through a continued dividend increases and share repurchases. 
And with that, we are ready to take questions.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Bruce Harting with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Bruce Harting with Barclays Capital.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: With 60% of growth coming from Rest of World, I'm just trying to circle the next time you have an earnings announcement, hopefully, we'll know one way or another the outcome of the fed decision and whether it's stalled or not. But is it one way to look at
componenttext: With 60% of growth coming from Rest of World, I'm just trying to circle the next time you have an earnings announcement, hopefully, we'll know one way or another the outcome of the fed decision and whether it's stalled or not. But is it one way to look at it of $2.2 billion of net revenue this quarter, I figure about 10% given your previous numbers came from issuers at U.S. debit, so you call that maybe $200 million. And in theory if that were reduced say, 20% just to pick a number or maybe worst case or $40 million a quarter, the other $2 billion of revenue is growing faster as you said with 60% of revenue growth coming from Rest of World, particularly strong in credit given that credit is much larger Rest of the World than debit. Is it one way to look at it and say that the other $2 billion of revenue not impacted by Durbin growing say, 15% will more than offset say, that $40 million decline and the $200 million of U.S. debit coming from issuers, is that one way try to size this in the second half if we get a worst case?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Without confirming any of the numbers, I think the mindset that we are conveying and you are picking up is that with that 45% of our net revenue in the quarter is now coming from outside the U.S.. That revenue, this quarter grew at 21%, twice what the gro
componenttext: Without confirming any of the numbers, I think the mindset that we are conveying and you are picking up is that with that 45% of our net revenue in the quarter is now coming from outside the U.S.. That revenue, this quarter grew at 21%, twice what the growth rate is of the U.S. at '10. And we were particularly pleased to see that this is the fifth straight quarter of positive payment volume growth in U.S. credit. And so, within the U.S. portfolio, which is being outgrown by Rest of World, credit is beginning to take a stronger presence and thereby putting debit in a different financial perspective than it was say, 12 months ago. So I think that thesis is exactly what we were trying to convey on the call. Thank you for asking.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Joe, I guess I just want to ask you I guess you, a little bit here with the eCommerce mobile strategy announcement later this month, is there anyway you can elaborate on that further? And I guess, I'd also ask if you can update us on your willingness to work with I'll call it, nonbank partners in the U.S., names like ISIS, which I believe is now opening things up outside of Discover?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't really expand on the first point because as I suggested, we are going to make an announcement and we'll begin with something in the middle to the end of next week. And so, you are going to have to hold off for a few days or several days in t
componenttext: Well, I can't really expand on the first point because as I suggested, we are going to make an announcement and we'll begin with something in the middle to the end of next week. And so, you are going to have to hold off for a few days or several days in that regard. As it relates to the second part of the question, obviously, one of the things that we're looking at is opening up new and different sources of revenue. And that would suggest that we'll be working with different types of entities who we have pretty much exquisitely worked with before. Having said that, I want to make perfectly clear, we're not going to do this at the expense of our primary customers and financial institutions.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to see and address the online in the quarter because all the calls that I'm getting post the release is on this. And I know Byron, you went through the details. It was based on the accounting changes on extras and all the things and so forth. But j
componenttext: I want to see and address the online in the quarter because all the calls that I'm getting post the release is on this. And I know Byron, you went through the details. It was based on the accounting changes on extras and all the things and so forth. But just to say on an apples-to-apples basis what would the year-over-year EPS compare have been? And as a follow-on, you said you will continually invest in growth initiatives with the margins of 62%. Does that mean they are not sustainable at current levels?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: So on the first run, I think what you're asking, Adam, on marketing is because we took the Visa out of the expense base going forward, does that have a P&L impact? Is that the question? If the revenue came out equal to the expenses, so while marketing is
componenttext: So on the first run, I think what you're asking, Adam, on marketing is because we took the Visa out of the expense base going forward, does that have a P&L impact? Is that the question? If the revenue came out equal to the expenses, so while marketing is down and it is down in part because of the removal of Extras and also because of timing, the full year impact of the change that we've made with Visa Extras is income statement neutral. So no impact on EPS and no impact on the full year guidance for marketing because when we guided, while marketing is down versus the same quarter last year, as always, given the campaign that we have last year relative to the Olympics, you would naturally expect it to be down somewhat. So we are still fully consistent with the guidance that we gave earlier for marketing. And the adjustments we made for Extras has no income statement impact. With regards to the margin at 62 for the quarter, that would be what you should take away is that we are increasingly investing in our products platforms to drive future growth. And the margin will simply be an outcome of the level of investment that we make and we continue to invest aggressively in that arena.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Dan Perlin with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Dan Perlin with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a question as it pertains to watching inflation, gas prices and food. I want to know what really has been your experience, where in a certain I guess, friction points price levels, which could impact the transaction growth relative to what you guys
componenttext: I have a question as it pertains to watching inflation, gas prices and food. I want to know what really has been your experience, where in a certain I guess, friction points price levels, which could impact the transaction growth relative to what you guys get from higher average ticket prices? And then, are you really concerned at current levels? Or would you be concerned at these levels, where kind of helped up held up for a long period of time?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Byron. Let me give you a few a little bit of factual perspective first. With regards to -- let's talk about this in the context of the U.S.. So for gas, historically, go back a year. At gas prices that we're roughly 30% less than that average, on
componenttext: This is Byron. Let me give you a few a little bit of factual perspective first. With regards to -- let's talk about this in the context of the U.S.. So for gas, historically, go back a year. At gas prices that we're roughly 30% less than that average, on average than they are today, we were running around 8% of total U.S. payment volume in the gas category. We refer to it as oil, the oil category. In the months of April, that was just a little over 10% of the U.S. payment volume, suggesting that the share had moved up about that's 25% increase in the share of U.S. payment volume. When you compare that to roughly based on our measures of 32% increase in the average price of gasoline, April versus about where we were a year ago, and you factor in that there is probably been some degree of consumption cutback given prices that are now posted in the $4-plus range. That is the immediate impact. We have not yet seen and it may be a bit early, we have not yet seen any specific call outs relative to trade outs on other spending categories, which may be in part due to the additional disposable income created by reductions and withholding tax and social security, so we're still trying to sort that out. Inevitably, there is probably going to be some friction. But at the moment, it's hard for us to identify it.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.
componenttext: The next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Byron, if we operate under the assumption that indeed, Durbin is not delayed, and as you said, you would adjust incentives to maintain volume, should we think about that, first of all, I'm assuming what you're seeing is you'd be above the high end of the
componenttext: Byron, if we operate under the assumption that indeed, Durbin is not delayed, and as you said, you would adjust incentives to maintain volume, should we think about that, first of all, I'm assuming what you're seeing is you'd be above the high end of the 16.5% range you set. And second, will that effectively be a one-time event concentrated in the second half of '11 and then you'd go back to more normalized levels in the future? Or is that a structurally higher level of volumes to support your incentives view?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me deal with the first part of your question. We delivered the first 6 months at 16% incentive as a percent of growth. And our guidance was 16% to 16.5%. That 16% to 16.5% guidance did assume that Durbin would not be delayed, that we would have some i
componenttext: Let me deal with the first part of your question. We delivered the first 6 months at 16% incentive as a percent of growth. And our guidance was 16% to 16.5%. That 16% to 16.5% guidance did assume that Durbin would not be delayed, that we would have some impact of Durbin before the end of the year and we provided for some degree of incentives in the event if that-that were to happen. Without knowing the exact timing, without knowing exactly how the rules will be promulgated, without knowing the timing, the implementation timing associated with those rules, those are some pretty big wildcards with regards to the incentives that we may or may not be putting on the table this fiscal year. And therefore, we are drawing attention to the fact that we've got a year in the bag at 16, but there's some significant uncertainties still to go. But some of those uncertainties we're contemplating. So don't automatically assume that were it to be -- we're it not to be delayed that we would necessarily be above that range. But where we end up is going to be a function of the timing and the exact wording of the rules. And I would say on the second, it's just hard to know with regards to how we would be deploying incentives today versus how we would do it under Durbin. The notion that incentives would be in play I think is a fair assumption. To what degree whether it be one time sustained, I think it will be, once we understand better than the environment ahead, we'll be much be better able to opine on that.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Dave Koning with Baird.
componenttext: The next question comes from Dave Koning with Baird.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Guys, I'm just wondering if the acceleration in credit growth is all being driven by just consumer references as incomes rise et cetera? Or if there is some external push from the banks that are just starting to push credit over debit towards deemphasizin
componenttext: Guys, I'm just wondering if the acceleration in credit growth is all being driven by just consumer references as incomes rise et cetera? Or if there is some external push from the banks that are just starting to push credit over debit towards deemphasizing debit?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Credit is typically much more discretionary in its use. And therefore, we have continued to see very strong debit growth, which is more nondiscretionary. As the economy recovers, our belief is that consumers in combination with more employment become more
componenttext: Credit is typically much more discretionary in its use. And therefore, we have continued to see very strong debit growth, which is more nondiscretionary. As the economy recovers, our belief is that consumers in combination with more employment become more willing to spend on discretionary side. From what we can see, this is still concentrated in the high-income segment of the market but driven by more discretionary spend and not coming at the expense of debit at this point.

componenttext: We are -- we don't actually guide to or disclose what the actual impacts are. But it is  a, conversions are accretive for us through this fiscal year. And we can address that again with fiscal year '12 coming up when we talk about our guidance for that time period at the end of the year. We'll address conversions or deconversions at that point but it should be accretive in each quarter for the balance of this fiscal year.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Joe, as you look at markets such as Asia, I mean clearly, it's a very strong growth trajectory. I was just curious on the headwind side, I mean, how do you feel about the competitive sort of landscape from a regional network perspective. We talked to thes
componenttext: Joe, as you look at markets such as Asia, I mean clearly, it's a very strong growth trajectory. I was just curious on the headwind side, I mean, how do you feel about the competitive sort of landscape from a regional network perspective. We talked to these folks over there and simply they continue to be pretty active?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a lot of competitive activity that is different in Asia than in the United States. I mean there is Union Pay. There's JCB. There's national payment systems considerations and so there's a lot going on. But we've been doing around the world i
componenttext: Well, there's a lot of competitive activity that is different in Asia than in the United States. I mean there is Union Pay. There's JCB. There's national payment systems considerations and so there's a lot going on. But we've been doing around the world in a lengthy period of time, we've had people on the ground for decades in most of these countries. And the fact that these economies are emerging and the electronic payment mechanisms we're becoming more and more prevalent, we continue to have a huge opportunity almost everywhere in the world. Now I am not being dismissive about the competition that we face. I mean obviously, there are areas of the world like China where we can't do business domestically. But I don't think -- I think that our numbers would suggest to you that we are doing quite well and increasing our volume in Asia and other parts of North America and other regions outside the United States. And so I'm pretty bullish on, where we will be on the next few years in that figure.

componenttext: Byron, maybe just sort of circling a little bit on sort of the confidence to go through Durbin, as you think about that longer term, is it the volume growth outside of the U.S., some of the mitigation strategies that you're talking about, what gives you guys the confidence? Or is it a combination of all of the above you guys have some visibility on obviously, where the growth of the businesses? But may be sort of on how you think about the mitigation efforts themselves in terms of post-Durbin rule et cetera?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it would be. This is Joe. It would be -- it would be kind of silly for me to sit here and tell you exactly what we're going to do because clearly it has something to do with the competition in the event that the rules change. But we certainly haven'
componenttext: Well, it would be. This is Joe. It would be -- it would be kind of silly for me to sit here and tell you exactly what we're going to do because clearly it has something to do with the competition in the event that the rules change. But we certainly haven't been passive as it relates to assuming what the various implications and scenarios could be coming out of Durbin whether it is delayed or it isn't delayed, what the final points from the fed would be. And so each of those cases, we have a different set of mitigation tactics that we would intend to use. I mean, obviously, we'll be doing some things that we wouldn't do across the board regardless of how things developed. But our suggesting to you in that we're comfortable that we are going to be valuable and a company predicated on confidence that we have as it relates to what we do. If that's sufficiently vague, I'm sorry.

componenttext: Well, I mean, look, if this gets back into what are the mitigation tactics that we're going to use, and I understand what FDR thinks and I understand that they are probably excited about the potential from their point of view. But frankly, I'm as excited about what we can do as they are about what they can do. And I'm really quite prepared to do what I need to do to compete with FDR. And at the risk of sounding, let's not, I'm not being flippant. I'm just -- I'm just, I have a considerably tied the real confidence that we'll be just fine.

componenttext: It makes sense that you have your incentives outlook in your 2012 outlook essentially on hold until we get clarity on the fed's debit rules. But I'm wondering if you could give us a way to dimension the percentage of your U.S. revenues that are attached to clients, where your incentive agreement would need to be altered if the feds chooses either alternative A or alternative B, under the no network exclusivity provision. In other words, how much of your U.S. revenue mix is subject to incentive agreement modifications under the Durbin amendment, if in the long run, recognizing that Durbin's timing is very unknown?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rod, let me try to be helpful in putting some perspective with 2 observations. The first one of which, since we're not going to specifically talk about revenue in the context that you asked. We are already public that roughly a little over 50% of cards ar
componenttext: Rod, let me try to be helpful in putting some perspective with 2 observations. The first one of which, since we're not going to specifically talk about revenue in the context that you asked. We are already public that roughly a little over 50% of cards are issued in the U.S., where Interlink is exclusive on the bank, number one. In the debit, where interlink is exclusive on the bank. Second, we have also said on a number of locations that most of our contracts are set up with incentive arrangements that are tied to volume. And so, we will naturally at our impetus want to revisit a number of those contracts to make sure that the incentives are structured in a way that makes sense given the legal environment that we will be under post-Durbin. I can't think of very many contracts at all that require us because of the legislation to revisit the contract. We're going to want to in order to adjust the incentives so that it is a win-win for both us and the financial institution.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that what I said earlier was that we recognize that it is as time moves on that mobile and eCommerce technology are going to consume a greater role in the electronic payments arena. And if we are going to remain as a viable player as we are
componenttext: Well, I think that what I said earlier was that we recognize that it is as time moves on that mobile and eCommerce technology are going to consume a greater role in the electronic payments arena. And if we are going to remain as a viable player as we are today and we are going to have to be out in front as it rolls in our interoperability, simplicity, security and factors of that nature. So we have been paying attention to that, the acquisitions that we have made, but that in the back of our mind. And we have a strategy both in the United States and other mature economies in different strategy in different parts of the world, where there are emerging economies that depend more on technology. So it is kind of bringing that together, the way that we think about that. What we've done, what we have ready to induce and what we will be contemplating doing as time moves on. So our point of view, it's significant and from our point of view, it is -- we are the better in the competition that we have to deal with has been because our solution is a more complete solution than what we've seen in market before. And so we've been reluctant to talk about it until we have put together and put together in an appropriate way were we can tell you something positive and significant and we can talk about how it all comes together. So that's how we are.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ships, it is gaining traction and we've supported it. We've made an announcement several months ago as it relate to our support globally. We didn't encourage it in the U.S. that there have been a lot of things going on as you all are probably aware of lik
componenttext: Ships, it is gaining traction and we've supported it. We've made an announcement several months ago as it relate to our support globally. We didn't encourage it in the U.S. that there have been a lot of things going on as you all are probably aware of like that Durbin, distracting issuers in the United States. But for cards to be global, chips are going to play a role and we encourage moving the chip technology. We don't necessarily encourage them into pins and chips. We encourage moving to chips and other forms of identification or authentication than what exists or existed here before. We don't believe that contact with chips would become something that is ubiquitous within the point of sale marketplace in the United States. And in the future, we didn't know that there will be specific things to which it is applicable and for which it will be used, but it won't necessarily be widespread tomorrow or the next day or in 2012, 2013.

componenttext: I think we have a terrific opportunity in both technology. And I did mention answering one or the other questions, I believe that the, we believe that not only, well, as it relates to the technology and just payments in general, we do believe that there are other sources of revenue that will be made available to us and are not now, that takes our CyberSource acquisition or PlaySpan acquisition and other things what we've done and what altogether we're pretty excited about the revenue that can come out of this in the future. Now let me caution you. I'm not talking about the spike in revenue in 2012. I mean this isn't something that happens overnight. It's something that evolves. But as I sit here and look at Visa and I look at our sources of revenue on our growth, I have to anticipate what is going to be fueling that growth 3 years from now, 4 years from now and what's going to happen next week? And so I think what we're going to talk about next week, we're putting things together. And mobile technology in particular will be something that we'll be happy, excited to be involved in as time moves on.
