componenttext: The next question comes from Tien-Tsin Huang with JPMorgan.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Joe, I guess I want to ask you, I guess you're teasing us a little bit here with the eCommerce mobile strategy announcement later this month, is there anyway you can elaborate on that further? And I guess, I'd also ask if you can update us on your willing
componenttext: Joe, I guess I want to ask you, I guess you're teasing us a little bit here with the eCommerce mobile strategy announcement later this month, is there anyway you can elaborate on that further? And I guess, I'd also ask if you can update us on your willingness to work with I'll call it, non-bank partners in the U.S., names like Isis, which I believe is now opening things up outside of Discover?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't really expand on the first point because as I suggested, we're going to make an announcement and we'll begin with something in the middle to the end of next week. And so, you're going to have to hold off for a few days or several days in tha
componenttext: Well, I can't really expand on the first point because as I suggested, we're going to make an announcement and we'll begin with something in the middle to the end of next week. And so, you're going to have to hold off for a few days or several days in that regard. As it relates to the second part of the question, obviously, one of the things that we're looking at is opening up new and different sources of revenue. And that would suggest that we'll be working with different types of entities and we have pretty much exquisitely worked with before. Having said that, I want to make perfectly clear, we're not going to do this at the expense of our primary customers and financial institutions.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Adam Frisch with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to address the 8 online in the quarter because all the calls that I'm getting post their releases is on this. And I know Byron, you went through the details. It was based on the accounting changes around extras and no Olympics this year and so fort
componenttext: I want to address the 8 online in the quarter because all the calls that I'm getting post their releases is on this. And I know Byron, you went through the details. It was based on the accounting changes around extras and no Olympics this year and so forth. But just to set an apples-to-apples basis, what would the year-over-year EPS compare have been? And as a follow-on, you said that you will continually invest in growth initiatives with the margins of 62%. Does that mean they're not sustainable at current levels?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: So on the first one, I think what you're asking, Adam, on marketing is because we took the Visa extras out of the expense base going forward, does that have a P&L impact? Is that the question? Because the revenue came out equal to the expenses, so while m
componenttext: So on the first one, I think what you're asking, Adam, on marketing is because we took the Visa extras out of the expense base going forward, does that have a P&L impact? Is that the question? Because the revenue came out equal to the expenses, so while marketing is down and it is down in part because of the removal of Extras and also because of timing, the full year impact of the change that we made with Visa Extras is income statement neutral. So no impact on EPS, and no impact on the full year guidance for marketing because when we guided, while marketing is down versus the same quarter last year, there's always, given the campaign that we have last year relative to the Olympics, you would naturally expect it to be down somewhat. So we are still fully consistent with the guidance that we gave earlier on marketing. And the adjustments we made for Extras no income statement impact. With regards to the margin at 62 for the quarter, that would be -- what you should take away is that we are increasingly investing in our products platforms to drive future growth. And the margin will simply be an outcome of the level of investment that we make and we continue to invest aggressively in that arena.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Dan Perlin with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Dan Perlin with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I had a question as it pertains to watching inflation, gas prices and food. I wanted to know what really has been your experience, where in a certain I guess, friction points or price levels, which could impact your transaction growth relative to what you
componenttext: I had a question as it pertains to watching inflation, gas prices and food. I wanted to know what really has been your experience, where in a certain I guess, friction points or price levels, which could impact your transaction growth relative to what you guys get from higher average ticket prices? And then, are you really concerned at current levels? Or would you be concerned if these levels, where kind of held up for a long period of time?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Byron. Let me give you a few -- a little bit of factual perspective first. With regards -- let's talk about this in the context of the U.S. So for gas, historically, go back a year. At gas prices that we're roughly 30% less than they average, on a
componenttext: This is Byron. Let me give you a few -- a little bit of factual perspective first. With regards -- let's talk about this in the context of the U.S. So for gas, historically, go back a year. At gas prices that we're roughly 30% less than they average, on average than they are today, we were running about 8% of total U.S. payment volume in the gas category. We refer to it as oil, in the oil category. In the month of April, that was just a little over 10% of U.S. payment volume, suggesting that the share had moved up about -- that's about a 25% increase in the share of U.S. payment volume. When you compare that to roughly based on our measures of 32% increase in the average price of gasoline, April versus about where we were a year ago, and you factor in that there is probably been some degree of consumption cutback given prices that are now posted in the $4-plus range. That is the immediate impact. We have not yet seen and it may be a bit early, we have not yet seen any specific call outs relative to trade outs on other spending categories, which may be in part due to the additional disposable income created by reductions in withholding tax and social security. So we're still trying to sort that out. Inevitably, there is probably going to be some friction. But at the moment, it's hard for us to identify it.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.
componenttext: The next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Byron, if we operate under the assumption that indeed, Durbin is not delayed, and as you said, you would adjust incentives to maintain volume, should we think about that, first of all, I'm assuming what you're saying is you'd be above the high end of the
componenttext: Byron, if we operate under the assumption that indeed, Durbin is not delayed, and as you said, you would adjust incentives to maintain volume, should we think about that, first of all, I'm assuming what you're saying is you'd be above the high end of the 16.5% range you set. And second, would that effectively be a onetime event concentrated in the second half of '11 and then you'd go back to more normalized levels in the future? Or is that a structurally higher level of volumes to support incentives in your view?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me deal with the first part of your question. We've delivered the first 6 months at 16% incentives as a percent of gross. And our guidance was 16% to 16.5%. That 16% to 16.5% guidance did assume that Durbin would not be delayed, that we would have som
componenttext: Let me deal with the first part of your question. We've delivered the first 6 months at 16% incentives as a percent of gross. And our guidance was 16% to 16.5%. That 16% to 16.5% guidance did assume that Durbin would not be delayed, that we would have some impact of Durbin before the end of the year and we provided for some degree of incentives in the event that, that were to happen. Without knowing the exact timing, without knowing exactly how the rules will be promulgated, without knowing the timing, the implementation timing associated with those rules, those are some pretty big wildcards with regards to the incentives that we may or may not be putting on the table this fiscal year. And therefore, we were drawing attention to the fact that we've got a year in the bag at 16, but there's some significant uncertainties still to go. But some of those uncertainties we're contemplated. So don't automatically assume that were it to be -- were it not to be delayed that we would necessarily be above that range. But where we end up is going to be a function of the timing and the exact wording of the rules. And I would say on the second, it's just hard to know with regards to how we would be deploying incentives today versus how we would do it under Durbin. The notion that incentives would be in play I think is a fair assumption. To what degree whether it be onetime, sustained. I think it will be -- once we understand better the environment ahead, we'll be much better able to opine on that.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Dave Koning with Baird.
componenttext: The next question comes from Dave Koning with Baird.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Guys, I was just wondering if the acceleration in credit growth is just all being driven by just consumer preferences as maybe their incomes arise et cetera? Or if there's some external push from the banks that are just starting to push credit over debit
componenttext: Guys, I was just wondering if the acceleration in credit growth is just all being driven by just consumer preferences as maybe their incomes arise et cetera? Or if there's some external push from the banks that are just starting to push credit over debit or just deemphasizing debit?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Credit is typically much more discretionary in its use. And therefore, we have continued to see very strong debit growth, which is more nondiscretionary. As the economy recovers, our belief is that consumers in combination with more employment, become mor
componenttext: Credit is typically much more discretionary in its use. And therefore, we have continued to see very strong debit growth, which is more nondiscretionary. As the economy recovers, our belief is that consumers in combination with more employment, become more willing to spend on the discretionary side. From what we can see, this is still concentrated in the high-income segment of the market, but driven by more discretionary spend and not coming at the expense of debit at this point.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Next question comes from David Hochstim, Buckingham Research.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

componenttext: Could you just give us maybe a better stance of how much deconversions affected the revenue and payments growth metrics this quarter, if we look at year-over-year comparisons this quarter versus the December quarter?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: We are -- we don't actually guide to or disclose what the actual impacts are. But it is a -- conversions are accretive for us through this fiscal year. And we can address that again with fiscal year '12 coming up when we talk about our guidance for that t
componenttext: We are -- we don't actually guide to or disclose what the actual impacts are. But it is a -- conversions are accretive for us through this fiscal year. And we can address that again with fiscal year '12 coming up when we talk about our guidance for that time period at the end of the year. We'll address conversions or deconversions at that point. But it should be accretive in each quarter for the balance of this fiscal year.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Don Fandetti with Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from Don Fandetti with Citi.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Joe, as you look at markets such as Asia, I mean there's clearly a very strong growth trajectory. I was curious on the headwind side, I mean, how do you feel about the competitive sort of landscape from a regional network perspective. We talked to some fo
componenttext: Joe, as you look at markets such as Asia, I mean there's clearly a very strong growth trajectory. I was curious on the headwind side, I mean, how do you feel about the competitive sort of landscape from a regional network perspective. We talked to some folks over there, and it seems like they are continuing to be pretty active?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of competitive activity that is different in Asia than in the United States. I mean there's China UnionPay, there's JCB, there's national payment system considerations. And so there's a lot going on. But we've been doing business around the
componenttext: There's a lot of competitive activity that is different in Asia than in the United States. I mean there's China UnionPay, there's JCB, there's national payment system considerations. And so there's a lot going on. But we've been doing business around the world in a lengthy period of time, we've had people on the ground for decades in most of these countries. And the fact that these economies are emerging, and that electronic payment mechanisms are becoming more and more prevalent, we continue to have a huge opportunity almost everywhere in the world. Now I'm not being dismissive about the competition that we face. I mean obviously, there are areas of the world like China where we can't do business domestically. But I don't think that -- I think that our numbers would suggest to you that we're doing quite well in increasing our volumes in Asia and other parts of Latin America and other regions outside the United States. And so, I'm pretty bullish on where we'll be on the next few years in that regard.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Julio Quinteros with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from Julio Quinteros with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Byron, maybe just sort of horn in a little bit on sort of the confidence to grow through Durbin, as we think about that longer term, is it the volume growth outside of the U.S., some of the mitigation strategies that you're talking about, what gives you g
componenttext: Byron, maybe just sort of horn in a little bit on sort of the confidence to grow through Durbin, as we think about that longer term, is it the volume growth outside of the U.S., some of the mitigation strategies that you're talking about, what gives you guys the confidence? Or is it a combination of all of the above? You guys have the visibility on obviously, where the growth of the business is? But maybe anyway to sort of hone in on how you're think about the mitigation efforts themselves in terms of post-Durbin world et cetera?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it would be -- this is Joe. It would be kind of silly for me to sit here and tell you exactly what we're going to do, because it clearly has something to do with the competition in the event that the rules change. But we certainly haven't been passi
componenttext: Well, it would be -- this is Joe. It would be kind of silly for me to sit here and tell you exactly what we're going to do, because it clearly has something to do with the competition in the event that the rules change. But we certainly haven't been passive as it relates to understanding what the various implications and scenarios could be coming out of Durbin, whether it is delayed or it isn't delayed, what the final links from the fed would be. And so each of those cases, we have a different set of mitigation tactics that we would intend to use. I mean, obviously, we'll be doing some things that we would intend to do across the board regardless of how things developed. But our suggesting to you that we're comfortable, that we are going to be valuable and a company predicated on confidence that we have as it relates to what we do. If that's sufficiently vague, I'm sorry.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a follow-up on that Joe, some of the things that would mitigate the effects on you wouldn't necessarily even be things that you would do, you might help them. But I was wondering about the idea of how much do you think of debit volume could be
componenttext: Maybe just a follow-up on that Joe, some of the things that would mitigate the effects on you wouldn't necessarily even be things that you would do, you might help them. But I was wondering about the idea of how much do you think of debit volume could be shifted either in more upscale customers up to credit or downscale customers to reloadable prepaid that would have kind of better economics for the issuer and for yourself as well? And would Visa be advantaged in that just because you tend to be partnered with the banks that have more robust credit card platforms like JPMorgan and BofA?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. I mean I don't -- your logic is good and then also [indiscernible] space is a significant investment. I can't tell you, it's hard to judge what percentage of debit a volume could move up or down in the way that you're suggesting. But I don't ce
componenttext: Well, yes. I mean I don't -- your logic is good and then also [indiscernible] space is a significant investment. I can't tell you, it's hard to judge what percentage of debit a volume could move up or down in the way that you're suggesting. But I don't certainly wouldn't be saying anything out of score or giving away any secrets if I suggested that there isn't a bank in the United States that isn't.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Craig Maurer with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question comes from Craig Maurer with CLSA.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yesterday, on First Data's earnings call, they have mentioned making significant investment in dynamic routing, whether that's premature or not depends on the Durbin delay or not. But I wanted to get your thoughts on the prospect of dynamic routing at the
componenttext: Yesterday, on First Data's earnings call, they have mentioned making significant investment in dynamic routing, whether that's premature or not depends on the Durbin delay or not. But I wanted to get your thoughts on the prospect of dynamic routing at the acquirer level and whether that would create a price war at the merchant level for debit?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, look, if this gets back into what are the mitigation tactics that we're going to use, and I understand what FDR thinks, and I understand that they're probably excited about the potential from their point of view. But frankly, I'm as excited
componenttext: Well, I mean, look, if this gets back into what are the mitigation tactics that we're going to use, and I understand what FDR thinks, and I understand that they're probably excited about the potential from their point of view. But frankly, I'm as excited about what we can do as they are about what they can do. And I'm really quite prepared to do what I need to do to compete with FDR. And at the risk of sounding -- let's not -- I'm not being flippant. I'm just -- I have a considerably hide the real confidence that we'll be just fine.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Rod Bourgeois with Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question comes from Rod Bourgeois with Bernstein.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: It makes sense that you have your incentives outlook and your 2012 outlook essentially on hold until we get clarity on the fed's debit rules. But I'm wondering if you could give us a way to dimension the percentage of your U.S. revenues that are attached
componenttext: It makes sense that you have your incentives outlook and your 2012 outlook essentially on hold until we get clarity on the fed's debit rules. But I'm wondering if you could give us a way to dimension the percentage of your U.S. revenues that are attached to clients, where your incentive agreement would need to be altered if the fed chooses either alternative A or alternative B, under the no network exclusivity provision. In other words, how much of your U.S. revenue mix is subject to incentive agreement modifications under the Durbin amendment, if in the long run, recognizing that Durbin's timing is very unknown?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rod, let me try and be helpful in putting some perspective with 2 observations. The first one of which, since we're not going to specifically talk about revenue in the context that you asked. We're already public that roughly a little over 50% of cards ar
componenttext: Rod, let me try and be helpful in putting some perspective with 2 observations. The first one of which, since we're not going to specifically talk about revenue in the context that you asked. We're already public that roughly a little over 50% of cards are issued in the U.S., where Interlink is exclusive on the bank, number one. In the debit, where Interlink is exclusive on the bank. Second, we have also said on a number of occasions that most of our contracts are set up with incentive arrangements that are tied to volume. And so, we will naturally at our impetus, want to revisit a number of those contracts to make sure that the incentives are structured in a way that makes sense given the legal environment that we will be under post-Durbin. I can't think of very many contracts at all that require us, because of the legislation to revisit the contract. We're going to want to in order to adjust the incentives so that it is a win-win for both us and the financial institution.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from James Friedman with Susquehanna.
componenttext: The next question comes from James Friedman with Susquehanna.

componenttextpreview: So Byron, I'm just going to just improvise here in light of your response to that prior question which was intriguing. I just want to kind of reiterate what it is that you have addressed so far with regard to volume and et cetera. So you have said that yo
componenttext: So Byron, I'm just going to just improvise here in light of your response to that prior question which was intriguing. I just want to kind of reiterate what it is that you have addressed so far with regard to volume and et cetera. So you have said that you're 16.5% for this year had contemplated already some impact from Durbin, but the comment you just made suggested that perhaps volume and incentive would be in your interest to reduce in fiscal '12, should Durbin actually proceed? Am I misinterpreting that comment?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're misinterpreting. The incentive contracts that we have in place -- most of them are based on volume growth. And if the routing provisions go into place, where the financial institution potentially has less influence over the actual routing, we
componenttext: Yes, you're misinterpreting. The incentive contracts that we have in place -- most of them are based on volume growth. And if the routing provisions go into place, where the financial institution potentially has less influence over the actual routing, we just have to look at the incentive provisions to make sure that they are reflective of the way the operating environment will conduct itself under legislation.

componenttext: Yes, there are no top 5 contracts scheduled for renewal, I want to say, for a good 18 months or more. We do from time to time, when the opportunity is attractive, we will look at early renewals. But in terms of major contract renewals, at the end of last year, we pretty much cleared the decks and don't expect, we have no scheduled major renewals for at least another 18 months.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that what I said earlier was that we recognize that as time moves on that mobile and eCommerce technology are going to consume a greater role in the electronic payments arena. And if we are going to remain as a viable player as we are today
componenttext: Well, I think that what I said earlier was that we recognize that as time moves on that mobile and eCommerce technology are going to consume a greater role in the electronic payments arena. And if we are going to remain as a viable player as we are today then we are going to have to be out in front as it relates to interoperability, simplicity, security and factors of that nature. So we have been paying attention to that, the acquisitions that we have made, that in the back of our mind. And we have a strategy both in the United States and other mature economies in a different strategy in different parts of the world, where there are emerging economies that depend more on technology. So it is kind of bringing that together, the way that we think about that. What we've done, what we have ready to induce and what we will be contemplating doing as time moves on. So our point of view, it's significant and from our point of view, it is -- we are better than any in the competition that we think we have to deal with, has been because our solution is a more complete solution than what we've seen in the market before. And so we've been reluctant to talk about it until we have put together and put together in an appropriate where we can tell you something positive and significant. And we can talk about how it all comes together. So that's where we are.

componenttext: There has been some recent announcements that suggests that EMV is gaining traction in the U.S. Can you talk about whether you're seeing that and share your thoughts what that would mean for Visa?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chips, it is gaining traction and we've supported it. We've made an announcement several months ago as it related to our support globally. We didn't encourage it in the U.S. There have been a lot of things going on as you are probably aware like the [indi
componenttext: Chips, it is gaining traction and we've supported it. We've made an announcement several months ago as it related to our support globally. We didn't encourage it in the U.S. There have been a lot of things going on as you are probably aware like the [indiscernible] acting, the Durbin acting. Distracting to issuers in the United States. But for cards to be global, chips are going to play a role and we encourage moving the chip technology. We don't necessarily encourage them into pins and chips. We encourage moving to chips and other forms of identification or authentication than what exist, have existed here before. We don't believe that contact with chips would become something that is ubiquitous within the point of sale marketplace in the United States in the near future. We didn't know that there will be specific things to which it is applicable and for which it will be used, but it won't necessarily be widespread tomorrow or the next day or in 2012, 2013.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, May 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we have a terrific opportunity in mobile technology. And I did mention answering one or the other questions, I believe that, we believe that not only, well, as it relates to the technology and just payments in general, we do believe that there are
componenttext: I think we have a terrific opportunity in mobile technology. And I did mention answering one or the other questions, I believe that, we believe that not only, well, as it relates to the technology and just payments in general, we do believe that there are other sources of revenue that will be made available to us that are not now, that takes our CyberSource acquisition or PlaySpan acquisition, and other things what we've done and when we put it altogether we're pretty excited about the revenue that can come out of this in the future. Now let me caution you. I'm not talking about the spike in revenue in 2012. I mean this isn't something that happens overnight. It's something that evolves. But as I sit here and look at Visa and I look at our sources of revenue and our growth, I have to anticipate what is going to be fueling that growth 3 years from now, 4 years from now, not just what's going to happen next week. And so I think that what we're going to talk about next week, the way we're putting things together. And mobile technology in particular will be something that we'll be happy -- excited to be involved in as time moves on.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jos. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Visa's Fiscal 2011 Third Quarter Conference Call. With us today are Joe Saunders, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Byron Pollitt, Chief Financial Officer. This call is currently being webcast o
componenttext: Thank you, Jos. Good afternoon, and welcome to the Visa's Fiscal 2011 Third Quarter Conference Call. With us today are Joe Saunders, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Byron Pollitt, Chief Financial Officer. This call is currently being webcast over the Internet and can be accessed on the Investor Relations section of our website at www.investor.visa.com. The replay of the webcast will also be archived on our site for 30 days. I will, continue of highlight today's commentary will be posted to our website prior to this call. Let me also remind you that this presentation may include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. By their nature, forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance. And as a result of a variety of factors, actual results could differ materially from such statements. These include setbacks in the global economy and the impact of new financial reform regulation. Additional information concerning those factors is available in our last 10-K on file with the SEC and can be accessed through the SEC website and the Investor Relations section of our website. For historical non-GAAP and pro forma-related financial information disclosed on this call, the related GAAP measures and other information required by Regulation G of the SEC are available in the financial and statistical summary accompanying our fiscal third quarter earnings press release. This release can also be accessed through the Investor Relations section of our website. With that, I'll turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack, and as always, thank you, all, for joining us today. Visa delivered another quarter of strong financial performance posting net revenues of more than $2.3 billion, a 14% increase over the same period last year. These revenue gains were drive
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack, and as always, thank you, all, for joining us today. Visa delivered another quarter of strong financial performance posting net revenues of more than $2.3 billion, a 14% increase over the same period last year. These revenue gains were driven by double-digit payment volume growth around the globe, strong cross-border activity and continued recovery in credit spend worldwide. Adjusted net income for the quarter, which excludes the gain from revaluing the Visa at court option was $883 million, a 23% increase over last year. This equates to adjusted diluted earnings per share of $1.26, a 29% increase over the third quarter of 2010. 
Our performance over the past quarter reaffirmed Visa's solid business foundation and strategy, including our diversified product and services offering, our strong client relationships and our commitment to accelerating growth in key markets worldwide. 
Before turning to the business highlights, I'd like to update you on Visa's activities to adapt to the new United States regulatory environment. As stated during our update call on July 6, overall, I continue to expect the impact resulting from regulation to be dilutive but manageable with fiscal 2012 bearing the majority of the financial impact. It is important to appreciate that we were prepared for a wide range of outcomes. And with the federal reserves final rules in hand, we have the clarity needed to execute on our strategies. We are now moving forward on multiple fronts and with a variety of new offerings for our clients. And today, I'd like to share with you at a high level a feel of our areas of focus. 
We will offer additional details in the coming quarters once we have had the opportunity to further discuss these strategies with our clients and partners. Regulation has dramatically altered the competitive environment in the United States and given merchant broad discretion over how transactions will be routed. Recognizing this new dynamic, we are resetting our business approach and implementing a number of new strategies for all products. 
Specifically for debit, we will continue to focus on maintaining Visa debt issuance through strong partnerships with our issuing clients, thereby positioning Visa to compete for as many transactions as possible. Equally important, we will ensure that Visa is positioned to compete for routing for merchants and acquirers by strengthening these important relationships. We are adapting Visa's business to deliver even more value to all participants in the value chain, while preserving our ability to grow and positioning Visa for continued leadership in the U.S. 
Our approach is based on multiple actions which were incorporated into the guidance we provided earlier this month. I'm going to address 2 of them now. 
First, we are modifying our economics in a way that we expect will result in a reduction in merchant cost in total and on the margin. The modifications include both fixed processing fees and a reduction in variable fees. We expect this will help us win routing decisions and maintain debit volume in the new environment. Specifically, Visa is implementing a new fixed acquirer fee called the network participation fee, which will apply to the acceptance of all of Visa products and is based on both the size of the merchant and the number of merchant location. This fee will allow Visa to continue investing in our secure, reliable and interoperable mobile payments network, a long-standing area of strength for our organization. These attributes are cornerstones of Visa's brand promise and it is critical that we make ongoing upgrades, innovations and enhancement. 
In fact, Visa facilitates issuers standing processing each day for more than 600,000 transactions, minimizing system disruption and ensuring more transactions to get completed. In order to reduce fees in the aggregate, Visa will also lower our variable processing fees for all Visa debit products across all market segments. The combination of fixed and variable fees offers merchants an even better incentive throughout more transactions over our network by providing them an opportunity to lower their per unit transaction costs and take advantage of economies of scale that are now more readily available to them. 
As I said a few moments ago, our 2012 guidance, which incorporates the reductions we expect to Visa's debit, volumes increase and the fees we charge, also reflects our appreciation of regulation change and plans in which we operate. 
We recognize that we need to focus more than ever on delivering greater value to both issuers and merchants to win debit routing while continuing to grow our successful credit business. 
In that regard, we are taking multiple actions to ensure we are well-positioned to compete for both issuance and routing. We will extend the merchants of all sizes through direct negotiations and through acquirers with successful partnership programs we have historically offered issuers. We will also increase our engagement with merchant associations to achieve the same goal. Now a broad set of acquirers and merchants can receive incentives from Visa in exchange for routing commitments. 
The second quarter element of our strategy focuses on additional investment and value-added services aimed at winning routing decisions. These include powerful merchant benchmark analytics, loyalty, rewards programs and realtime mobile messaging to drive merchant sales growth. 
For example, we continue to make progress on our realtime messaging program, including the GAP recent decision to expand their existing program across more brands in their portfolio as well as new agreements with the Sports Authority and the Kangaroo Express, a leading convenience store operator in the Southeastern United States with more than 1,600 location. 
With these actions, we are resetting our baseline economics for debit in the United States and positioning Visa to grow from here. We are 100% prepared. We are fully engaged with our key stakeholders. We are focused on their needs and we are moving forward. 
Taken together, our strategies will provide Visa with a strong foundation to adapt to the new landscape while also generating sufficient revenue to make the investments needed to drive forward the future of this industry. Of course, while the regulatory process generated headlines over the last 13 months, the overwhelming majority of Visa's revenues are derived from products and geographies that are completely untouched by VisaNet. In that regard I'm pleased to say that Visa's employees maintained their focus and continued to advance our growth agenda. 
In the U.S., we saw a continued strong performance in credit, posting Visa's sixth consecutive quarter of positive growth. Of note, a credit posted particularly strong performance growing 3 times faster than the overall credit category. Building on that success, we announced a multiyear agreement with United Continental Holdings to continue to issue co-branded Mileage PLUS Visa card. The recent merger of the United and Continental Airlines will result in the consolidation of their card portfolios under mileage plus and the combined entity will begin exclusively issuing Mileage PLUS Visa cards to all new customers beginning January 1, 2012. An important aspect of this major co-brand program is the proportionally larger number of affluent card carriers and the greater cross border volume usage associated with Mileage PLUS Visa card, all benefits to Visa's overall growth. 
Another key renewal was with Disney with whom we have enjoyed an important co-branding and promotional relationship for many years. Outside of the U.S., International markets are increasingly important contributor of Visa's growth, increasing payment volume by 17%, which is driving approximately 60% of the company's overall revenue growth. In line with our strategic aspiration to grow Visa's business outside the U.S., we continue to make progress on our long-standing commitment to invest in key markets which show the greatest potential. 
In critical markets, including Brazil, Russia, Japan, the GCC, Mexico and Sub Saharan Africa, we have tailored acceleration plans to substantially increase revenue growth over a 5-year horizon. We will continue to target additional countries for our investment in 2012 and beyond. 
For example, in Russia, one of the fastest-growing countries globally, we are focused on delivering the core Visa product with value proposition and continuing to expand acceptance. We are investing to enhance mass card and premium credit offerings and delivering products like prepaid and Visa Money transfer to our Russian issuers and consumers. 
In Brazil, where the acquiring landscape is changing, Visa is accelerating growth of processed transactions versus new acquirer relationships in renewing issuing partnerships. We continue to differentiate ourselves by delivering superior products across our core portfolio of credit, debit, small business and commercial solutions. 
We also continue to advance our core product growth in India, establishing new or expanded agreements with several large clients including the Life Insurance Corporation of India as well as the State Bank of India. As I mentioned earlier in the quarter, we signed a multiyear agreement to support Visa debit products across the State Bank of India franchise. In just a few short months, over 1 million Visa debit cards has been issued as part of this program. 
In Japan, we are accelerating growth by driving more sophisticated product offerings such as co-brand programs with major issuers, merchants and commercial card programs that deliver solutions to more mature electronic payments environments. For example, we recently launched a debit program with Arizona Bank, Japan's fourth-largest financial institution. It's our first traditional debit program in that market and we are hopeful that it will lead to similar programs with other clients, accelerating the migration towards electronic payments in Japan's traditionally cash-centric economy. And we are partnering with clients and governments and investing in long-term growth in developing markets in Africa, Latin America and South Asia to accelerate efforts to advance financial inclusion and ultimately grow domestic transaction growth. 
On the innovation front, we have taken several steps to bring new products and solutions to market. We continue to make progress on Visa's next-generation e-commerce and mobile payment solutions announced in May, including a focus on single click and aliasing capabilities. We believe these elements of the Visa offering will help to differentiate and deliver value to the other NFC-only solutions recently announced. This remains a top priority for the organization and we are moving full speed ahead towards broad commercial availability. 
As we've said all along, Visa firmly believes in open approach is the key to success in mobile commerce. So in addition to building Visa's own capability, our strategy must also enable Visa payments on third-party platforms. That's why last week, we announced an agreement with Isis to join their consortium and we continue to engage in productive discussions with other potential partners. 
Part of our efforts to make mobile a reality in emerging markets, we completed our acquisition of Fundamo, a leading mobile wallet software provider for emerging markets with over 40 programs in more than 25 countries. I can report that the integration is progressing well and we are now focused on building managed services for issuers and mobile operators around the Fundamo platform. Additionally, we are developing capabilities to overlay a virtual Visa pre-paid account on the closed loop accounts managed by Fundamo and other wallet platforms. 
Since our announcement, we have received substantial interest from issuers and mobile operators in Asia and Latin America. We are also taking action to further tap into the creativity and the expertise of the developer community, an increasingly critical participant in the creation and rollout of new payment technology. Today, our existing developer center has more than 6,000 active developers using our tools and resources to build Visa payment functionality into websites for mobile applications, which in turn brings more merchants into the Visa network, ultimately, driving transactions and payments growth. Additionally, through the center, Visa helps to reduce e-commerce transaction risks, which means even more transactions are approved and flow through the network. This makes Visa a more attractive payment network partner.  To accelerate these efforts, we will launch our expanded Visa developer center in the current quarter, combining our existing PlaySpan and CyberSource developer activities into a single platform while also introducing direct connectivity to VisaNet for the first time. By connecting directly to VisaNet, we can offer to our merchant partners and financial institution customers faster and easier access to Visa products and services, making them more competitive and ultimately driving incremental revenue growth. 
On the e-commerce front, CyberSource's business continues to gain traction in the marketplace. During the quarter, billable transactions totaled just over $1 billion, a very strong 38% growth rate over the same period a year ago. We secured a number of new business wins with major merchants, including Twitter and. We continue to expect solid results in this part of our business as e-commerce growth remains strong in the United States and internationally. 
Finally, we continue to deliver on our long-standing commitment to return excess cash to shareholders. Today, we are pleased to announce that our Board recently authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase program. This comes on the heels of completing our $1 billion share repurchase program authorized in April. At approximately $77 per share, we retired 13.7 million shares in the quarter. This brings our repurchases in fiscal 2011, including escrow funding actions, $2.8 billion. 
In conclusion, as we reorient the U.S. debit business in the wake of the new regulations, we will simultaneously pursue our growth strategies both at home and abroad. Our commitment to our clients, new product rollouts and ongoing innovation combine to make Visa's value proposition more compelling than ever. And we are prepared to use our comprehensive array of products and functionalities to win in the marketplace. Visa remains a strong, globally oriented growth company as we move ahead. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Byron.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. I'll begin with some overall observations. First, Visa's 14% net revenue growth was once again broad based with solid 9% growth in the U.S. and a very strong 22% growth rate in rest of the world. Over 62% of the quarter's revenue growth ca
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. I'll begin with some overall observations. First, Visa's 14% net revenue growth was once again broad based with solid 9% growth in the U.S. and a very strong 22% growth rate in rest of the world. Over 62% of the quarter's revenue growth came from outside the United States. This means non-U.S. revenue is now 44% of Visa's total, up from 41% in the third quarter of fiscal year 2010. 
Second, U.S. revenue growth has been supported by 6 consecutive quarters of positive credit payment volume growth. Most recently, the months of May and June comped at 8% and 12%, respectively, which continues the strong growth we have seen all year. We continue to be encouraged by this trend. 
Third, price incentives for the quarter as a percent of growth revenue was 16.2%, down from 16.7% in the second quarter. Through the first 3 quarters of the year, incentives as a percent of gross revenue was 16.1%, in line with the lower end of our guidance. However, as we stated on our update call on July 6, we expect client incentives for the full fiscal year to be at the top end of the 16% to 16.5% range based on the pacing of our contract pipeline and potential Q4 partnership contracts that provide merchants incentive aimed at further encouraging Visa routing preference. 
Fourth, as first discussed back in January, we sold our 10% stake in Visa Vale, a Brazilian prepaid issuer. Though we expect to book a gain as investment income in our second quarter, we actually recorded a gain in Q3 once we receive the necessary Brazilian regulatory approval. The net benefit to Visa in the quarter was $85 million pretax and $44 million after tax. 
Finally, as we did in the fourth fiscal quarter last year, we revalued the Visa Europe court option, which had a positive noncash impact to our earnings this quarter. The $122 million decrease in the value of the option is nontaxable, is recorded in other income and is solely due to decline in Visa's TE ratio relative to historical level. It does not reflect any change in the likelihood that Visa Europe will exercise the put. The put option is not valued on our balance sheet at $145 million. 
Eliminating this impact, provides a cleaner picture of our operating performance on yields and adjusted earnings per share of $1.26 for the quarter. 
Now let's turn to the numbers. First, I will cover our global payment volume and transaction trends for both the March and June quarters as well as the results through July 21. I'll then cover the financial highlights of our fiscal third quarter followed by our guidance outlook for fiscal years 2011 and 2012. 
Global payment volume growth for the June quarter in constant dollars was 13%, relatively flat from the March quarter. We saw the following breakdowns in the June quarter: in the U.S., payment volume growth was 10%, a slight decrease from the 12% growth we saw in the March quarter; rest of the world payment volume on a constant dollar basis grew at 17%, up 2 points from the 15% growth rate in the March quarter. More recently, through July 21, U.S. payment volume growth came in at 10%. Although not yet available, based on the trends we saw during the third quarter, we expect rest of world payment volume growth to be higher. Global cross-border volume delivered a solid 14% growth rate on a constant dollar basis in the June quarter, up slightly from a 13% rate in the March quarter. We have seen some rebound in inbound travel to Japan, the Middle East and North Africa but it is still too early to gauge the longer term trends. Through July 21, cross-border volumes on a constant dollar basis grew 18%. 
Transactions processed over Visa's network totaled 13 billion in the fiscal third quarter, an 11% increase over the year ago period and modestly behind the 13% growth rate we saw in the March quarter. Through July 21, processed transactions posted growth of 10%. 
Now turning to the income statement. In our fiscal third quarter, gross revenue of $2.8 billion was up 14% from the similar period in 2010. Net operating revenue in the quarter was $2.3 billion, a 14% increase year-over-year, driven by strong growth in regions outside of the U.S., continued recovery in the U.S. economy, previously enacted pricing changes and solid cross-border transaction growth. 
Moving to the individual revenue line items. Service revenue was $1.1 billion, up 21% over the prior year period. This is reflective of strong payment volume growth in the March quarter and the impact of pricing adjustments. Data processing revenue was $886 million, up 12% over the prior year's quarter based on strong transaction growth rates for both Visa process and CyberSource transactions. 
International transaction revenue was up 15% to $652 million, reflecting continued strength in cross-border volumes during the period. As I mentioned, client incentives as a percent of gross revenue came in at 16.2% and are running at 16.1% fiscal year-to-date, on track with expectations. Total operating expense for the quarter is $977 million, up 10% from the prior year. As a reminder, these results include operating expenses for CyberSource, PlaySpan and Fundamo, none of which were included in Q3 of the prior year. While marketing expense was up, approximately $70 million on a sequential quarter basis. This was due to the timing of planned campaign and is consistent with our full year guidance of less than $900 million. 
In the U.S., we have continued to rightsize our spend and refined our marketing focus to put greater investment toward digital media. We have also focused on marketing efforts on driving greater cross-border transaction growth. As a reminder, last October, we announced an earnings neutral change in income statement presentation related to revenue and operating expense associated with certain pass through activity. Consistent with this announcement, $52 million of revenue and expense, which was booked in Q3 fiscal year 2010, did not reoccur in Q3 fiscal year 2011. In Q3, this represented 3 percentage points of revenue growth. 
The foreign exchange impact on net revenue in the third fiscal quarter was moderated by our hedging activities and contributed 2 percentage points of growth. Our operating margin for the quarter was 58%, on target with our expectation for the full year. Capital expenditures were $89 million in the quarter and now total $236 million year-to-date. 
Given the pace of our investment in technology, infrastructure and growth initiatives, we now expect our full year 2011 capital spending to be moderately above $300 million. 
On the acquisition front, the PlaySpan acquisition had a dilutive impact to earnings per share of $0.01 for the third quarter. For the full year of 2011, we anticipate a dilutive impact to earnings per share of $0.04. The Fundamo acquisition had a dilutive impact to earnings per share of $0.01 for the third quarter. Full year EPS dilution is also expected to be $0.01. Finally, our recorded tax rate for the period was 35% including the favorable impact from the nontaxable revaluation of the Visa Europe transaction. Adjusting to exclude the impact, the tax rate would have been 38%. On an as-adjusted basis we continue to expect full year, rate to be consistent with our guidance. 
As we announced on July 6, we completed the $1 billion share repurchase program authorized by our Board in April. During the quarter, we spent $1.1 billion to repurchase 13.7 million shares at an average price of $77.36. Year-to-date, Visa has spent $2.8 billion to effectively repurchase 37.8 million shares at an average price of $74.12. At the end of the quarter, we had 691 million shares outstanding on an as-converted basis. 
Visa remains committed to returning excess cash to shareholders. And to this end, as Bill mentioned at the outset, our Board of Directors authorized a new $1 billion repurchase plan through July 20, 2012, which will execute at prices we feel are attractive relative to the long-term value of Visa. 
As to guidance, for the back half of 2011, given results to date and to reiterate what we told you on the July 6 call, we expect to deliver revenue growth in the 11% to 15% range and EPS growth of better than 20%. Client incentives are expected to come in at the top end of the 16% to 16.5% range. And we are now expecting capital expenditures to be moderately above $300 million for the year, up from our prior range of $250 million to $275 million. 
Our net revenue outlook for 2012 stands at high single to low double-digit growth while earnings per share growth is expected to be mid  to high teens range. We will have additional guidance metrics for fiscal 2012 when we report our fourth quarter earnings in October. 
With that, we are ready to take questions.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jason Kupferberg with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jason Kupferberg with Jefferies.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask a question on the network participation fee and thanks for the disclosures around some of your post-Durbin strategies there. Can you talk a little bit about that network participation fee in the context of some of the what sounded like
componenttext: Just wanted to ask a question on the network participation fee and thanks for the disclosures around some of your post-Durbin strategies there. Can you talk a little bit about that network participation fee in the context of some of the what sounded like are fee reductions from merchants and merchant acquirers? Just trying to understand from a Visa point of view how you envision all that netting out on the merchants/acquiring side of your business?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that our intention is clear and that is to affect this change in our infrastructure while at the same time reducing fees to all merchants in every category. So the variable fee reductions are obviously an offset to fixed fee. If you look at our 20
componenttext: I think that our intention is clear and that is to affect this change in our infrastructure while at the same time reducing fees to all merchants in every category. So the variable fee reductions are obviously an offset to fixed fee. If you look at our 2012 guidance, it presumes that there will be a deterioration in our debit card guidance for the year. We said that 2012 will be the low point. So that is the net result, the net result is that we won't do as well as we have here for in the debit card business at least in 2012. Hopefully, we can grow off of what we do in 2012 and 2013. But what we have done is in our opinion, consistent with helping to ensure that Visa will be successful in the long run and within the spirit and the intention of the regulation.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.
componenttext: The next question comes from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to get a little bit more color on the expense line on a go-forward basis. The personnel and admin lines are fairly elevated. I was just wondering is that the run rate to consider on a go-forward basis? And also just in the card service the ma
componenttext: I was hoping to get a little bit more color on the expense line on a go-forward basis. The personnel and admin lines are fairly elevated. I was just wondering is that the run rate to consider on a go-forward basis? And also just in the card service the margin, that seems a little lighter for this quarter sequentially relevant to past quarter so I was hoping to get some color there.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the personnel, in particular, the expense line items, no, that would, at least on a percentage increase that is not the run rate. So in the personnel line in particular, a little over 55% of the year-over-year increase is due to the personnel costs ass
componenttext: On the personnel, in particular, the expense line items, no, that would, at least on a percentage increase that is not the run rate. So in the personnel line in particular, a little over 55% of the year-over-year increase is due to the personnel costs associated with CyberSource, PlaySpan and Fundamo. None of which were in Q3 of the prior year. So we will have a lapping for one more quarter for CyberSource, a few more quarters for the other 2. And we will give more color on the run rate with regards to expenses in the context of our margin, operating margin at the Q4 earnings call. No real call outs on the service fee. We were pretty pleased with the yields which held pretty firm sequentially over the 2 quarters. So from that vantage point, no call outs.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Don Fandetti with Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question comes from Don Fandetti with Citigroup.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Joe, I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about the new debit pricing strategy. How the issuers might be thinking about that just given sort of the actions that you try to balance between the merchant acquirers and issuers. And also does that impa
componenttext: Joe, I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about the new debit pricing strategy. How the issuers might be thinking about that just given sort of the actions that you try to balance between the merchant acquirers and issuers. And also does that impact your ability to raise pricing in the future?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think that anything that we've done is inconsistent with our commitment to our current clients. In fact, most of what we've done and the restructuring that we've done is to ensure that we can continue to serve them and we can continue to help them
componenttext: I don't think that anything that we've done is inconsistent with our commitment to our current clients. In fact, most of what we've done and the restructuring that we've done is to ensure that we can continue to serve them and we can continue to help them run profitable businesses. I think what we've done also reflects our focus on making sure that everyone in the value chain has higher expectations of what they can expect in the future and that, that helps regenerate the whole, at least from a debit card point of view, it helps sustain and regenerate the whole process of electronic payments continuing to move forward. There was a second part of the question...

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Pricing.
componenttext: Pricing.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It does constrain our ability to price. I don't think that we have done anything that constraints our ability to take actions in the future that we deem to be appropriate. I think the key word here is deemed to be appropriate. And right now, we don't have
componenttext: It does constrain our ability to price. I don't think that we have done anything that constraints our ability to take actions in the future that we deem to be appropriate. I think the key word here is deemed to be appropriate. And right now, we don't have any intention of raising any prices in the United States I think that we're in the position that we're comfortable with. And that's the way we're going to look at it going forward for the time being.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Craig Maurer with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question comes from Craig Maurer with CLSA.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could help us understand a little more the magnitude of change between the former pricing structure in debit and what's coming perhaps in the context of the 20% of revenue, 20% plus of revenue that you discussed as being generated from U.
componenttext: I was hoping you could help us understand a little more the magnitude of change between the former pricing structure in debit and what's coming perhaps in the context of the 20% of revenue, 20% plus of revenue that you discussed as being generated from U.S. debit. Now I'll totally shift the topic. This morning, CL Brazil held their conference call. They discussed in a very brief time. is issued over 0.25 million cards and that growth rate is accelerating. And I'm curious if you take into account that the bank's pushing or mainly Visa issuers, are you seeing any impact to your growth rate of cards enforced down in Brazil?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So, Byron, let me respond to both questions. With regards to a deeper portion of the impact on the 20%, I think the way we've chosen to respond to that for now is related to what we described on our last call that in preparing for a new post-Durbin enviro
componenttext: So, Byron, let me respond to both questions. With regards to a deeper portion of the impact on the 20%, I think the way we've chosen to respond to that for now is related to what we described on our last call that in preparing for a new post-Durbin environment, there are a number of ways this can play out competitively. We have run a variety of scenarios. We have used those to inform the revenue range we gave you all at the July 6 call. And I think you'll recognize that there's a lot of market reaction here yet to unfold. Strategies need to play out before we can be more descriptive about these impacts. And as they do, we will update appropriately. Having said that, we do believe that the primary impact of the Durbin legislation will be felt in 2012 and we would expect to regain some revenue growth momentum in this arena in 2013. With regards to CLO, it was contemplated all along that CLO would be entering in this market. It is a lower income profile, lower spend-oriented market segment and that's a segment very different from the one that we currently occupy. And so from that vantage point, where we feel that the enormous growth we're experiencing in Brazil will continue and the developments we're seeing today are not unexpected.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Clint Boehner, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question comes from Clint Boehner, Morgan Stanley.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Regarding your comments on the July 6 call and this call as well on net revenue growth in fiscal '13 can regain momentum. This is a very important nuance for investors in the Street. I was wondering if you can provide us with a little roadmap on how you s
componenttext: Regarding your comments on the July 6 call and this call as well on net revenue growth in fiscal '13 can regain momentum. This is a very important nuance for investors in the Street. I was wondering if you can provide us with a little roadmap on how you see that occurring. I mean I appreciate the color you gave today on Russia, Brazil and India but those are going to take some time. So where is the fiscal '13 reacceleration going to come from? And then given that margins are pretty healthy already, could we still expect the same spread between revenue and earnings growth and why?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe the best way to respond to that again, I'm going to elevate a little bit and describe some of the high-level baseline on assumptions that we informed the 2012 guidance recognizing that on the fourth quarter earnings call that is typically when we wo
componenttext: Maybe the best way to respond to that again, I'm going to elevate a little bit and describe some of the high-level baseline on assumptions that we informed the 2012 guidance recognizing that on the fourth quarter earnings call that is typically when we would provide more metrics describe '12 and we'll see about '13. So in '12, we are projecting global payment volume growth off of current trends adjusted for the investments we are making related to our country acceleration strategy. In U.S. debit in particular, we do expect as Joe mentioned, a decrease in yield. We expect to lose some routing, weighted more to '10. We expect some volume shift from Signature to '10. We expect much of that to play out in '12. Therefore, becoming part of our base in '12. And so from a revenue standpoint, by the time we run into 2013, we are benefiting from strong growth outside the United States that is accelerated based on investments we are making in a number of key markets to amplify the growth in those markets and with post-Durbin impacts substantially embedded in the 2012 base with our strategies in place and gaining more traction with each passing quarter, that is the underpinning of why we would expect to see revenue begin regaining momentum in '13.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Rod Bourgeois with Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question comes from Rod Bourgeois with Bernstein.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So first a quick clarification and then I guess an easy question. Your guys debit payment volume growth decelerated by a couple points from March to June. I mean I guess I'm wondering, if Durbin potentially had a disruptive impact at all in your opinion o
componenttext: So first a quick clarification and then I guess an easy question. Your guys debit payment volume growth decelerated by a couple points from March to June. I mean I guess I'm wondering, if Durbin potentially had a disruptive impact at all in your opinion on the debit volume growth. And then the meatier question is really how do you expect your debit competitors might react to the altered debit structure your rolling out? It seems desirable to avoid pricing competition but it seems price-based competition is now somewhat of a certainty given that the other competitors are likely to respond to your altered structure. Do you expect the other networks to be more aggressive on pricing? And to the extent that they are, are you prepared to do something with your financial to try to buffer the impact such as cutting advertising expenses or something along those lines? Can you give us an idea, you run multiple scenarios on how competitors might react but if those worse scenarios play out, where pricing competition gets more aggressive on a more aggressive side, you have a kind of a plan b to for the impact.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the first one. So Rod, with regards to the deceleration in debit, which you will also see in and that is also the explanation for why Visa process transactions dipped a bit in the quarter. What you're seeing is the tail -- the runoff, so to s
componenttext: So I'll take the first one. So Rod, with regards to the deceleration in debit, which you will also see in and that is also the explanation for why Visa process transactions dipped a bit in the quarter. What you're seeing is the tail -- the runoff, so to speak, of Chase-WaMu conversion and the initial ramp up of the SunTrust change. And the combination of those 2 completely explain the drop in growth rate down, dropping growth rate on Visa processed transactions. So that's the answer to the first question. Joe?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer to the second question is, yes. We thought very clearly and very deeply into what our notions about what our competition would do. We think we have put ourselves in a position where we are more than capable of responding. We have no inten
componenttext: Well, the answer to the second question is, yes. We thought very clearly and very deeply into what our notions about what our competition would do. We think we have put ourselves in a position where we are more than capable of responding. We have no intention nor do we think we have to start a race to the bottom. We do have contingency plans. We are very confident in the guidance that we gave you for 2012. And if you can remember, we withheld giving specific guidance on 2012 for quite some time. And we didn't actually say anything until after the regulations came up so that we could match what the rules said to what our plans were. We've done that. We're confident we're going to get where we said, where we say we're going to go. I just would add to what Byron said earlier, he explained why 2013 will go up. I will also tell you that I've I think 2012 is an extraordinarily achievable objective.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Tien-Tsin Huang with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Tien-Tsin Huang with JPMorgan.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of quick clarifications on each question I had as well. Just on the 60 versus lower variable fee strategy, I just want to make sure, is this just for debit or is it also for other Visa products? And also the impact on the P&L, is this -- I
componenttext: I have a couple of quick clarifications on each question I had as well. Just on the 60 versus lower variable fee strategy, I just want to make sure, is this just for debit or is it also for other Visa products? And also the impact on the P&L, is this -- I'm just trying to reconcile the strategy versus Byron, the guidance that you talked about in the fourth quarter and the incentives picking up to win routing decisions. Is that one  and the same or are they 2 different strategies? And then my primary question was just around International volumes that did accelerate. It looks like, yes, it did accelerate in every region. So how much of that acceleration is from new programs being launched versus just a pickup in underlying same-store growth or is same-store secular growth obviously a lot of focus on the macro today?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, so on the last one it is same-store growth without question. That's the accelerator. 60, all products and the 2 different strategies. So when we talked about entering into some additional merchant partnerships, trading incentives for routing preferen
componenttext: Yes, so on the last one it is same-store growth without question. That's the accelerator. 60, all products and the 2 different strategies. So when we talked about entering into some additional merchant partnerships, trading incentives for routing preference, that is a different strategy. It's all contemplated in the guidance that we've given you for '12. But it's 2 different strategies with the network participation fee and the introduction of lower variable transaction cost being a separate pricing strategy, all contained within the guidance we gave for 2012 .

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jim Kissane with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jim Kissane with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just another question on the network participation. Do you have a sense on what portion Visa will directly negotiate with merchants and what portion will be negotiated by the acquirers? And will merchants be able to opt out if they don't want to go along
componenttext: Just another question on the network participation. Do you have a sense on what portion Visa will directly negotiate with merchants and what portion will be negotiated by the acquirers? And will merchants be able to opt out if they don't want to go along with the program and stick with the old variable structure?

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll leave het financials to Byron but as it relates to opt out, they can opt out if they don't want to accept Visa cards.
componenttext: I'll leave het financials to Byron but as it relates to opt out, they can opt out if they don't want to accept Visa cards.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And yes, we do. It is -- we have a sense as to the proportions. That's part of the scenarios that we have run. For competitive reasons, of course, you wouldn't expect us to be very specific on the call so I will honor that expectation and not be.
componenttext: And yes, we do. It is -- we have a sense as to the proportions. That's part of the scenarios that we have run. For competitive reasons, of course, you wouldn't expect us to be very specific on the call so I will honor that expectation and not be.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And let me go back and just remind everyone that this fixed fee that you're talking about is not a fee that sits on top of what merchants are paying. It is part of what we consider to be a reduction in the fees that merchants will pay. And that I think th
componenttext: And let me go back and just remind everyone that this fixed fee that you're talking about is not a fee that sits on top of what merchants are paying. It is part of what we consider to be a reduction in the fees that merchants will pay. And that I think that is extraordinarily important because to mischaracterize it would be a mistake and undeserving.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I would add, Jim, that when Joe said earlier, the strategies in part intended to honor kind of the spirit of the new regs, this will allow merchants to begin realizing more economies of scale on the incremental transactions as they grow their volumes.
componenttext: And I would add, Jim, that when Joe said earlier, the strategies in part intended to honor kind of the spirit of the new regs, this will allow merchants to begin realizing more economies of scale on the incremental transactions as they grow their volumes. And we thought that, that was an important design element of the pricing structure going forward. And so the notion of introducing a fixed component, having a lower variable and then allowing the variable to be the one in play as merchants grow their volumes, honors one of the objectives of this regulation.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Julio Quinteros with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from Julio Quinteros with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Visa, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011

componenttext: Hey, Brian, just a clarification. Just a second ago you said this would imply to all products. Did you mean credit and debit products or do you just mean all debit products?
